facts.fact_text: The Indonesian rupiah dipped toward IDR 16,880 per dollar on Friday.

evidences.evidence_text: The Indonesian rupiah dipped toward IDR 16,880 per dollar on Friday, moving closer to last month’s record trough of 16,985.

facts.fact_text: Moody’s cut Indonesia’s credit rating outlook to negative from stable on Thursday.

evidences.evidence_text: Sentiment weakened after Moody’s cut Indonesia’s credit rating outlook to negative from stable on Thursday, citing declining policy predictability.

facts.fact_text: GDP growth reached 5.11% in 2025, missing the government’s 5.2% target.

evidences.evidence_text: Domestically, GDP growth reached 5.11% in 2025, missing the government’s 5.2% target despite solid Q4 momentum, reinforcing expectations that Bank Indonesia may have scope to ease policy further this year.

facts.fact_text: Forex reserves fell in December from a nine-month high.

evidences.evidence_text: Meanwhile, forex reserves fell in December from a nine-month high, narrowing the external buffer.

facts.fact_text: The dollar index notched a two-week high.

evidences.evidence_text: Globally, the dollar index notched a two-week high as broad risk-asset selloffs lifted demand for safe havens.

claims.claim_text: Prolonged deterioration could erode Indonesia’s long-standing credibility.
claims.author: rating agency

evidences.evidence_text: The rating agency highlighted concerns over policy effectiveness and weakening governance, cautioning that prolonged deterioration could erode Indonesia’s long-standing credibility.

claims.claim_text: Bank Indonesia may have scope to ease policy further this year.

evidences.evidence_text: Domestically, GDP growth reached 5.11% in 2025, missing the government’s 5.2% target despite solid Q4 momentum, reinforcing expectations that Bank Indonesia may have scope to ease policy further this year.

evidence.evidence_text: Sentiment weakened after Moody’s cut Indonesia’s credit rating outlook to negative from stable on Thursday, citing declining policy predictability.

Domestically, GDP growth reached 5.11% in 2025, missing the government’s 5.2% target despite solid Q4 momentum, reinforcing expectations that Bank Indonesia may have scope to ease policy further this year.
Globally, the dollar index notched a two-week high as broad risk-asset selloffs lifted demand for safe havens.
Sentiment weakened after Moody’s cut Indonesia’s credit rating outlook to negative from stable on Thursday, citing declining policy predictability.
